Graphical abstract In-situ reconstructed Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure on Co3O4 boosted adsorption and activation of nitrate to nitrite and the formed Co(OH)2 promoted the dissociation of water to active hydrogen for hydrogenation of nitrogen species to ammonia, unveiling origin of the improvement of NO3RR performance for enhanced energy supply in zinc-nitrate battery. Revealing the dynamic reconfiguration of catalysts and the evolution of active species during catalysis, elucidating and regulating the reconfiguration mechanism are paramount to the development of high-performance electrochemical nitrate reduction (NO3RR) to ammonia. In-situ characterizations can precisely track reaction process and unveil the origin of activity enhancement. Here, in-situ reconstruction of pre-catalyst Co3O4 fabricates a stable heterojunction Co(OH)2/Co3O4 to boost NO3RR to ammonia. In-situ generated heterojunction accelerates the transformation of *NO3 to *NO2, while Co(OH)2 promotes the dissociation of water to active *H species for the hydrogenation of *N species, and thereby improving the deoxygenation and hydrogenation ability of NO3RR to NH3 and achieving a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) about 96.2% and a high NH3 production rate of 218.5 μmol h−1 mgcat −1 at −0.3 V. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations verified that in-situ formed active species Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 markedly decreased the energy barrier of *NO3 → *NO2 and accelerated the hydrogenation step of *NH → *NH2 → *NH3. Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure-based Zn-NO3 − cell achieves excellent energy supply (1.22 V), a high ammonia yield rate (48.9 µmol h−1 cm−2), and a high FE (91%). The establishment of the structure–activity relationship during NO3RR provides guidance for designing advanced electrode materials, and the in-situ evolution of species on the electrode surface unveils the intrinsic nature of improved catalytic performance. Keywords Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction In situ reconstruction Ammonia synthesis Zinc-nitrate battery 1 Introduction Ammonia, as one of the most pivotal chemical products in modern industries, serves not only as the cornerstone of the fertilizer industry, but also as a widely recognized high-energy density hydrogen carrier [1–3]. Currently, 96% of ammonia in the world is produced through the energy-intensive (approximately 2% of global energy consumption) and high-emitting (1.2% of global CO2 emissions) Haber-Bosch process [4]. The development of green and efficient ammonia synthesis methods has always been an eagerly pursued goal. Nowadays, excessive nitrates caused by over-fertilization and industrial wastewater are discharged into surface waters and underground aquifers, threatening human health. The conversion or removal of nitrate is a very vital step in restoring the global disturbed nitrogen cycle [5–7]. In recent years, with the rapid development of electrochemistry technology in sustainable and renewable energy conversion and storage, electrocatalytic nitrate reduction (NO3RR) to ammonia has attracted widespread attention due to its mild reaction conditions and good compatibility with renewable energy [8,9]. The rational design of high-performance electrocatalyst is the key to explore the complicated eight-electron transfer issue (NO3 – + 6H2O + 8e– → NH3 + 9OH–) and unveil the origin of high efficiency of electrochemical NO3 – to NH3 conversion. It is well known that dynamic structural evolution on electrocatalysts driven by external conditions (applied voltage bias, electrolytes, pH and designable cell device, etc.) and intrinsic characteristics (such as surface structure, chemical composition and morphology, etc.) strongly affect electrocatalytic behavior of catalyst, and these factors in turn also increase the difficulty of design and synthesis [10–16]. Of course, a coin has two sides. The electrocatalysts can also be rationally designed and efficiently fabricated by tracking and unveiling structural evolution and understanding the mechanism. Owing to the alteration of surface structure and phase under applied potential, most transition metal compounds, in fact, are thermodynamically unstable and would like to transform these instable components into thermodynamically stable specie during electrocatalysis [11–16] to achieve a relatively stable state through dynamic structural evolution for the electrochemical CO2 conversion [11–14], hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [11,12,14,16], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [12,14,15], oxygen/nitrogen reduction reaction (O/NRR) [11,14], and nitrate to ammonia reduction (NO3RR) [8]. In terms of electrocatalytic NO3RR, cobalt-based electrocatalysts have been widely used [17–40], because of high selectivity to NH3, high intrinsic activity of the evolved Co species and an ability to modulate a key rate-determining step of nitrate to *NO2 and dissociate water into H* for the hydrogenation of *N species to NH3 during NO3RR. The redox reaction on cobalt electrode surface generates intermediates (Co2+ and Co3+ species) and their synergistic effect in the Co2+–Co3+–Co2+ redox cycle boosts the adsorption and activation of NO3 − to *NO2 and the production of H* for the *N species to NH3, and thereby enhancing selectivity and activity to NH3 [17,18]. Metallic Co nanoarrays stemmed from electrochemical reduction of Co(OH)2 significantly enhanced NO3RR performance with ≥96% Faradaic efficiency (FE), and suppressed HER process due to a large number of exposed active sites on nano-structured Co surface over Co(OH)2 benefiting from the hydrogenation of *N species to NH3 [19,20]. High conductive metal Co can efficiently enhance the transfer efficiency of charge carriers on Co/Co(OH)2 heterostructure, and corresponding electroxidation of metallic Co to high-value state Co species can also improve NO3RR performance, further demonstrating the vital role of Co0/Co2+. Note that the electron-deficient Co nanocrystals interacted with pyridine nitrogen from N-doped carbon material can also promote the electrocatalytic NO3 − reductions to NH3 without oxidation state alteration [21], implying the coordination environment of the active Co centers strongly affecting electronic structures and thereby regulating NO3RR to NH3 efficiency [22]. Moreover, the fabrication of Co-based alloys can effectively modulate the performance of NO3RR to NH3, such as PdCo bimetallene [23], sub-20 nm thick nanoribbons fabricated by sub-5 nm Cu/Co nanophases [24], CuCo nanosheets [25], carbon nanofiber-embedded Mo-Co catalyst [26], Ru(Fe)–Co alloy [27,28], metallic CoNi-terminated catalyst on copper foam [29], and recent PdCuCo medium-entropy-alloy metallene [30]. In addition, the electrochemical transformation of Cu-Co binary sulfides into potential-dependent core–shell Cu/CuO x and Co/CoO phases can also promote NO3RR to NH3 [31]. All these studies revealed a pivotal phenomenon—the reconstruction and the alteration of electron configuration of electrode surface strongly affect the efficiency of nitrate reduction to NH3. Hollow CoP nanospheres and CoP nanosheet arrays on carbon materials were explored to corroborate the role of various evolved intermediates for NO3RR to NH3 [32,33]. Similarly, synergistic catalytic effect between [W-O] and CoP in the dual-site W-O-CoP catalysts was corroborated to promote the performance of nitrate reduction to ammonia [34]. To further concentrate on the performance of Co-based electrode-catalyzed NO3 − to NH3, CoO-loaded graphene electrode reached >98% FE toward NH3 [35], and protic ionic liquid-modified Co3O4 achieved an optimal FE of 84.7% by modulating the electrode surface microenvironment [36]. More recently, the study showed that Co3O4-electrocatalyzed NO3RR activity is highly dependent on the geometric location of the Co site, and the NO3RR prefers to occur at octahedral Co (CoOh) rather than tetrahedral Co (CoTd) sites [37]. Investigations based on CoP, Co and Co3O4 as model electrocatalysts revealed that CoP evolved into core-shelled CoP/Co(OH)2 and CoP/Co before NO3RR through simultaneous redox and electroreduction processes, and Co underwent three steps in the NO3RR process, namely, spontaneous redox of Co with NO3 − to generate *NO2 and form Co/Co(OH)2, electroreduction of Co(OH)2 to Co, and electrocatalytic conversion of *NO2 to NH3, while stable Co3O4 species steadily catalyzed deoxygenation and hydrogenation of NO3 − to NH3 [38]. The formation of β-Co(OH)2 has been previously observed in the RuCo alloy-catalyzed NO3 – to NH3 [39]. Additionally, a tri-metallic CuCoAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) catalysts also afforded a 99.5% FE and a yield rate of 0.22 mol h−1 g−1 for NO3RR to NH3 [40]. Although these explorations solved some issues, analyzing and accurately well-determining surface species, deducing reconstruction mechanism of catalyst surface, exploring factors of alteration of active sites, and constructing a correlation between the reconstructed active species and origin of promotion of performance, which are necessary prerequisites for designing efficient catalysts. Herein, we investigate in-situ dynamic reconstruction of pre-catalyst Co3O4 during NO3RR to NH3 in alkaline solution, and fully reveal the formation of a stable Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction structure and origin of the improvement of performance of NO3RR to NH3. The in-situ formed Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction enhances adsorption of nitrate and decreases the energy barrier of *NO3 to *NO2, while the Co(OH)2 accelerates the dissociation of H–OH to active *H, and thereby promoting the transformation of NO3 – to NO2 – and nitrate reduction to ammonia in the solution, and achieving a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) about 96.2% and a NH3 yield rate of 216.2 μmol h−1 mgcat − 1 at −0.3 V vs. RHE. Operando characterizations are used to monitor the alteration of surface structure and phase and the formation of intermediates during NO3RR. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further corroborate the crucial role of in-situ reconstructed heterostructure and new phase. Moreover, Zn-NO3 − battery assembled with Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure achieves excellent performance of power generation (1.22 V) and high ammonia yield rate (48.9 µmol h−1 mgcat −1), as well as a high FE (91%) at 8 mA cm−2. This work paves a path for exploring the nature of the reconfiguration process of Co3O4 under reduction potential, deepens the understanding of the structural evolution of cathode electrocatalyst during electroreduction, and provides guidance for the design of cathode electrocatalyst. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalyst design for the electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction to ammonia It is well known that the NO3RR involves eight-electron coupled nine-proton transfer (NO3 − + 6H2O + 8e− → NH3 + 9OH−), in which the conversion of nitrate (NO3 −) to nitrite (NO2 −) is considered to be the limiting step [41–43]. Frontier molecular orbital theory proposes that the oxidation–reduction reaction involves the transfer of electrons from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of the reducing agent to the high-energy lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the oxidizing agent [44]. NO3 − has a high-energy empty anti-bonding π* orbital, i.e., LUMO, and the outer orbital (3d) of Co is the HOMO orbital. The transformation of electrons from HOMO of reductant to LUMO of the oxidant leads to the occurrence of redox reaction. NO3RR is a multi-step complicated heterogeneous electrocatalytic reaction, in which electrons are transferred from a solid electrocatalyst to adsorbed NO3 –, resulting in the destabilization and dissociation of the N–O bond (204 kJ mol−1) [45]. According to group theory, Fig. 1 a shows the molecular orbital diagram and LUMO of NO3 –. Note that the high energy (5.62 eV, 1384 cm−1) of the LUMO makes it difficult for electrons to be injected into the LUMO of NO3 –. Based on band theory, the highest occupied state (HOS) of catalyst is equivalent to the HOMO in the frontier molecular orbital theory. Therefore, the transfer of electrons from the HOS of the electrocatalyst to the LUMO of NO3 – is conducive to the NO3 − reduction. As shown in Fig. 1b, the energy difference between the HOS of the electrocatalyst and the LUMO of NO3 – serves as the barrier for electron transfer and is the fundamental limitation for efficient electrochemical synthesis of ammonia. One direct approach to address this issue is to enhance the HOS of the electrocatalyst by tuning the local structure. The valence band maximum (VBM) of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is 0.435 and 0.374 eV, respectively, and the corresponding the conduction band minimum (CBM) is −0.865 and −0.906 eV. Electron on the valence band of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 transferred to the conduction band only needs 1.28 eV, lower than 1.30 eV of Co3O4, implying that NO3 − adsorbed on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 readily accepts these electrons from the conduction band to perform the activation of nitrate to nitrite. It is well known that Co3O4 is a typical narrow-bandgap p-type oxide semiconductor with low conductivity, poor hydrophilicity and weak adsorption property for NO3 –, which is not conducive to the deoxygenation of NO3 – to NO2 –. In addition, the electroreduction process can induce the structural evolution, which enables Co3O4 undergo obvious structural changes under the action of applied voltage [46], and therefore accelerating or weakening electron transfer for the alteration of catalytic performance. Notably, electron transfer is relevant to the electronic structure of a material. It is well known that the valence band spectrum provides a measure of the energy distribution of electrons in the valence band, which is critical for understanding the electronic structure of a material. The valence band spectrum of material essentially plots the number of electrons emitted from the valence band as a function of their binding energy. As shown in Fig. S1, the valence band spectrum of Co3O4 showed a high binding energy. The formation of Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 enables the valence band spectrum of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 have a low binding energy, implying the formation of Co(OH)2 accelerating electron transfer. Based on ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) adsorption spectra and Tauc plots (Fig. S2), the band gaps (ΔEg) of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 and Co3O4 are calculated to be 1.28 and 1.30 eV, respectively, indicating that the Co(OH)2 formed by the reconstruction up-shifts HOS of Co3O4, and therefore reducing the barrier of electron to be injected into LUMO of NO3 –. As a result, in-situ reconstructed Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction on Co3O4 can effectively reduce the energy barrier of NO3 – to NO2 –, thereby improving the catalytic efficiency (Fig. 1c). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterization Pre-catalyst Co3O4 was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction at 120 °C and post-thermal treatment at 400 °C in air. X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern confirmed the successful synthesis of high-purity Co3O4 sample with face-centered cubic symmetry (Fd-3m, Fig. S3). Scanning/transmission electron microscopy (S/TEM) images show that the pre-catalyst Co3O4 has a characteristic nanosheet structure consisting of uniform nanospheres (Fig. 2 a, and Fig. S4). The lattice fringes indexed as reflection planes (111), (311), (222) and (400) are easily observed and the corresponding lattice spacings are 0.465, 0.243, 0.232 and 0.202 nm, respectively (Fig. 2b), clearly verifying crystalline structure of pre-catalyst Co3O4. The energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mappings (Fig. S5) further prove the uniform distribution of elements Co and O in the Co3O4 pre-catalyst. Subsequently, such a Co3O4 sample was dispersed through ultrasonic treatment and uniformly deposited onto carbon paper (CP) as the working electrode for NO3RR. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and chronoamperometry curves were measured at −0.3 V vs. RHE in 1 M KOH electrolyte solution containing 0.1 M NO3 − and the results are shown in Figs. S6 and S7. The LSV curve after the reaction is shown Fig. S8. Under the same voltage, the current density of both HER and NO3RR is improved, indicating that the surface of the as-prepared sample may occur reconstruction during the reaction. Meanwhile, the change of catalyst surface was monitored by SEM (Fig. S9). TEM image (Fig. 2c) shows a slight structural change of catalyst after the reaction. The lattice fringes belonging to (111) plane from Co3O4, (001) and (011) reflection planes from Co(OH)2 can be observed (Fig. 2d), further indicating the co-existence of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2 phases. Moreover, EDX elemental mappings (Fig. S10) did not show significant alteration, implying the new formed Co(OH)2 stemming from the transformation of Co3O4 by reconstruction during the reaction. Furthermore, XRD pattern of Co3O4 (Fig. 2e) after electrocatalytic NO3RR for 30 min also corroborated the formation of β-Co(OH)2 [47]. Note that the appearance of Raman peak of Co(OH)2 at 496 and 615 cm−1 also indicates the occurrence of phase transformation from Co3O4 to Co(OH)2 during the reaction (Fig. S11) [48]. In addition, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results further confirmed the transformation process. Compared with initial Co3O4 (Fig. 2f), the content of Co2+ increased after reaction, and the area of defective oxygen in O 1s increased (Fig. S12). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra showed the increase of oxygen defects in Co3O4 after NO3RR reaction (Fig. S13a), implying that the formation of new phase Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 electrode surface results in the generation of oxygen defects. These results provide enough evidences to verify the formation of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction interfacial structure by in-situ reconstruction of pre-catalyst Co3O4 during NO3RR process. Note that the generation of oxygen defects in Co3O4 can promote the adsorption and activation of nitrate, but how to eliminate or minimize the effect of oxygen defects for enhanced ammonia synthesis is a tremendous challenge. It is also a relatively complex task to simultaneously maintain structural integrity of electrode Co3O4 and promote its efficient catalytic activity. Based on the environment of electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia, the optimization of various parameters, such as applied potential range, electrolyte composition, reaction temperature and pre-modification of Co3O4, can probably minimize the generation of oxygen defects. EPR spectra of Co3O4 electrode after NO3RR for 30 min under various applied potentials were measured (Fig. S13b). The results showed that EPR signals increased with increasing applied reduction potential, indicating the enhancement of surface oxygen defects. Obviously, a low applied reduction potential is beneficial to prevent the formation of oxygen defects, but is unfavorable for the generation of ammonia. A high applied potential can result in oxygen over-release leading to the generation of oxygen defects. Hence, it is difficult to completely eliminate the influence of oxygen defect during the electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia at a relatively high applied reduction potential (conducive to the formation of ammonium production). 2.3 Mechanistic investigations To deeply understand the structural evolution of catalyst Co3O4 in 0.1 M NO3 − aqueous solution, operando characterizations were performed at the multi-scale level to obtain dynamic structure information of the catalyst. First, operando XRD measurements were performed to determine the evolution of crystalline phase. As can be seen in Fig. 3 a, the ex-situ XRD patterns clearly showed the appearance of the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 18.7° and 39.1° corresponding to the planes (001) and (011) of β-Co(OH)2 as the cathodic reduction potential increased to −0.3 V vs. RHE. The intensity of diffraction peak of reflect plane (011) at 2θ = 39.1° from β-Co(OH)2 gradually increased with increasing absolute value of potential. In addition, time-dependent in-situ XRD patterns showed an initial gradually increasing diffraction intensity until a stable diffraction intensity with increasing reaction time (Fig. S14), while the characteristic diffraction peaks of Co3O4 still remained, indicating that the dynamic reconstruction of new species was only limited on the catalyst surface, and internal Co3O4 structure could not be converted completely. This result is in good agreement with HRTEM images observed. The lattice fringes observed and the corresponding lattice spacing also clearly proved the crystalline structure of in-situ formed β-Co(OH)2 and the preservation of crystalline Co3O4. To identify the evolution of dynamic reconstruction, potential-dependent in situ Raman spectra of Co3O4 during NO3RR process were measured. As shown in Fig. 3b, initial Co3O4 at the open circuit potential (OCP) shows four characteristic bands at 480 cm−1 (strong, Eg), 523 cm−1 (strong, F2g), 620 cm−1 (weak, F2g), and 690 cm−1 (very strong, A1g). The Eg, A1g and F2g vibrations gradually weakened until completely disappeared with increasing absolute value of potentials from 0.1 to 0.5 V vs. RHE. Simultaneously, a new Raman peak emerged at 501 and 615 cm−1 assignable to Co(OH)2, and its intensity gradually increased with increasing reduction potentials, indicating that the Co3O4 surface was converted into Co(OH)2 during the reaction [49]. The oxidation states of Co under different reduction potentials were quantitatively analyzed by in-situ XPS (Fig. S15). After electrocatalytic reaction for 10 min, the fitted Co 2p XPS spectra obtained at various reduction potentials (Fig. 3c) showed that the proportion of Co2+ gradually increased with increasing reduction potentials compared with that at OCP, revealing partial reduction of Co3+ in Co3O4 to Co2+ (Fig. S16). Note that the peak of Co2+ in Co3O4 after NO3RR shifts to high binding energy in comparison with initial Co 2p XPS in Co3O4, due to the formation of β-Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction structure and a strong electronic interaction between β-Co(OH)2 and Co3O4 as well as the charge transfer from β-Co(OH)2 to Co3O4 in the heterogeneous interfacial structure. These findings clearly reveal that the occurrence of NO3RR process strongly depends upon reconstruction of phase on catalyst surface from metal oxide to metal hydroxide (β-Co(OH)2) and in-situ reconstructed metal hydroxide actually acts as active centers. The electrocatalytic NO3RR performance was performed in an H-type electrolytic cell with three electrodes in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with 0.1 M NO3 −. The pre-catalyst Co3O4 was supported on CP as the working electrode of NO3RR, and 50 CV cycles were carried out at the reduction potential until the curves coincide to obtain a stable Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure (Fig. S17). LSV curves (Fig. 4 a) show a significant increase on the current density of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 in 0.1 M NO3 − solution compared to single Co3O4 and Co(OH)2. Obviously, single Co3O4 or Co(OH)2 is not a good electrocatalyst for the NO3RR to NH3 due to the absence of heterostructure interface, the corresponding single Co(OH)2 is worse than Co3O4 without phase transformation, only Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure indicated a high catalytic behavior, showing a strong synergistic effect between Co(OH)2 and Co3O4, and also implying the enhancement of electron transfer ability at heterojunction interface. This result is in good agreement with the valence band spectra measured and Tauc plots in Figs. S1 and S2. More importantly, the formation of Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 is inevitable during electrocatalysis, and Co3O4 provides Co2+ source to fabricate Co(OH)2 layer in this case. For the stable Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure, Tafel slope is smaller (187 mV dec−1) than that (219 mV dec−1) of Co3O4 (Fig. S18), indicating that NO3RR in the heterojunction has more favorable reaction kinetics and a fast electron transfer rate. At the same time, the onset potential of NO3RR on Co3O4 (−0.018 V vs. RHE) is much higher than that on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 (0.098 V vs. RHE), confirming that energy barrier of NO3 − reduction to NH3 on Co3O4 is higher than that on heterojunction β-Co(OH)2/Co3O4. To evaluate the NO3RR efficiency, the conversion rate of NO3 −, the production rate of NH3 and FE were quantitatively analyzed by UV spectroscopy according to the standard curve (Fig. S19). When potential ranges from 0 to −0.4 V vs. RHE, the FE reaches a maximum about 91.3% for Co3O4 at −0.2 V vs. RHE and about 96.2% for Co(OH)2/Co3O4 at −0.3 V vs. RHE (Fig. 4b), which are higher than that of Co(OH)2, although Co(OH)2 also indicated certain catalytic ability for NO3RR to NH3 with increasing reduction potential. Note that the FE of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is almost the same at −0.2 V vs. RHE. With increasing reduction potential from 0 to −0.4 V vs RHE, the production rate of NH3 for both electrocatalysts Co(OH)2/Co3O4 and Co3O4 correspondingly increased, but Co(OH)2/Co3O4-catalyzed NH3 production rate about 216.2 μmol h−1 mgcat −1 was much higher than that of Co3O4 (178.7 μmol h−1 mgcat −1) (Fig. 4c), implying that the Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure has a high catalytic activity for NO3RR compared to original Co3O4 and Co(OH)2. Obviously, the results from Fig. 4a–c further corroborated the crucial role of heterostructure and synergistic effect between Co(OH)2 and Co3O4. Notably, as a comparison, the NH3 yield and FE of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 are very competitive with those reported previously for NO3RR electrocatalysts (Table S1). Moreover, the conversion rates of nitrate over Co3O4, Co(OH)2/Co3O4 and Co(OH)2 under different reduction potentials after reaction for 3 h are shown in Fig. S20a, the Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is significantly higher than that of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2. The selectivity of ammonia and conversion of nitrate at −0.3 V vs. RHE for Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is higher than Co3O4 (Fig. S20b), probably due to the promoting effect of Co(OH)2 and synergistic effect between Co(OH)2 and Co3O4 on the conversion of NO3 − to NO2 − and a fast conversion of NO2 – to NH3 at the existing heterostructure interface at initial stage (about 30 min). This implies that a stable heterojunction is beneficial for adsorption and conversion of NO3 − to *NO2 − and the formed *NO2 − species are rapidly converted to NH3 through a multistep process, which results in an overall reduction in NO2 − concentration in solution (see below). To elucidate the promoting effect of new formed Co(OH)2 on the nitrate reduction activity, the contents of NO2 −, NO3 − and NH3 in electrolyte were measured at −0.3 V vs. RHE. As shown in Fig. S21, when Co3O4 is used as the working electrode, the content of NO3 − gradually reduced with increasing electrochemical reaction time. After being reacted for 10 min, the concentration of NO2 − and NH3 in electrolyte solution reached 56 and 36 ppm, respectively. Note that at initial reaction time within 30 min, the concentration of NO2 − in solution gradually increased, implying a fast conversion of NO3 – to NO2 – and a sluggish conversion rate of NO2 – to NH3. However, with extension of reaction time (after 40 min) NO2 – concentration in electrolyte solution markedly decreased and the corresponding NH3 significantly increased, hinting a remarkable improvement of conversion rate of NO2 – to NH3 through multistep process. Interestingly, when pre-prepared Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction is used as the working electrode (Fig. 4d), NO2 – concentration stemmed from the conversion of NO3 − reached 124 ppm while NH3 is 96 ppm after being reacted for 10 min, which is much higher than those of Co3O4 electrode, clearly indicating that the presence of Co(OH)2 is conducive to the conversion of NO3 − to NO2 −. With extension of reaction time (about 20 min), NO2 – concentration remarkably decreased and NH3 continuously increased, further unveiling a pivotal role of a stable Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction for the improvement of conversion rate of NO2 – to NH3. This result also directly confirms the importance of in-situ formed Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 surface. After 10 cycles, the Faradaic efficiency of ammonia did not decrease significantly, indicating the excellent stability of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction structure (Fig. S22) and Co center as active sites for the occurrence of nitrate reduction to ammonia. In addition, after Co(OH)2/Co3O4 electrocatalyzed NO3RR for 30 min, 6 h and 12 h, the XRD patterns of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 collected were measured. As shown in Fig. 2e and Fig. S14, after reaction for 30 min, XRD pattern confirmed the formation of new phase Co(OH)2 formation, but with gradually increasing reaction time from 30 min to 6 h and 12 h, the stable structure of the catalyst Co(OH)2/Co3O4 was still preserved, confirming the high stability of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure. Interestingly, when SCN− as a molecular probe was added into electrolyte, the current density of NO3RR remarkably decreased significantly (Fig. S23), due to the strong interaction of SCN− with metal active sites poisoning activity and suppressing adsorption of nitrate on metal center [43,50]. In terms of reaction kinetics, addition of NO3 − and NO2 − in electrolyte markedly declined open-circuit potential of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 (Fig. 4e and Fig. S24), clearly revealing that more NO2 – molecules are adsorbed onto the Co(OH)2 surface in Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure [51], and implying that the in-situ formed Co(OH)2 is conducive to the adsorption of NO3 − and NO2 −. Interestingly, as a comparison, the electrocatalytic performance of single β-Co(OH)2 confirmed by SEM image and XRD pattern (Fig. S25) is lower than those of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 based on current density, Faradaic efficiency and NH3 production rate (Fig. 4a–c). This result can only confirm that β-Co(OH)2 is active species during NO3RR, and indirectly implies a crucial role of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction. Moreover, surface morphology of β-Co(OH)2 after NO3RR slightly changed, but its phase structure still preserved, implying the occurrence of surface reconstruction (Fig. S26). To deeply understand the role of different catalysts, the apparent activation energies (E a) for NO3RR were obtained by conducting the reaction at different temperatures according to Arrhenius equations [52]. As shown in Fig. 4f, E a (1.52 kJ mol−1) of Co(OH)2/Co3O4-electrocatalyzed NO3RR is lower than 1.99 kJ mol−1 of Co3O4 and 2.29 kJ mol−1 of Co(OH)2, further corroborating in-situ formed Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure significantly reducing the activation energy barrier of the reaction. To further explore the origin of NO3RR catalytic performance over different catalysts, the intrinsic activity of catalysts was investigated by the normalization of the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA). As illustrated in Fig. S27, ECSA of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is higher than that of Co3O4 in 1 M KOH electrolyte, meaning that Co(OH)2/Co3O4 can provide more active sites for adsorption of NO3 −. Moreover, the LSV curve of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 normalized to ECSA still has a high current density in comparison with Co3O4 (Fig. S28), indicating highly inherent activity of Co(OH)2/Co3O4. Based on NH3 production rate and conversion of NO3 −, it is obvious to find that synergistic reaction of NO3 – and H2O drives NO3 − reduction—the occurrence of deoxygenation of *NO x and hydrogenation of *N species. As shown in Fig. S29, the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is smaller than that of Co3O4, showing that the Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure has better electrical conductivity during the NO3RR process, and thereby efficiently promoting charge transfer at the electrolyte/electrode interface. Note that with the extension of reaction time for Co3O4 electrode, R ct continuously declined. After 3 h, the R ct in NO3 − solution decreases from 72.5 to 17.2 Ω (Fig. S30 and Table S2), directly corroborating in-situ constructed Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction markedly accelerating charge-transfer ability and significantly promoting catalytic performance for NO3RR [48]. Obviously, with increasing reaction time, the decline in arc diameter in electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) implies lower impedance and a faster kinetics due to improved charge transfer process and increased reaction rate, which is caused by forming Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction and increasing oxygen defects. To further explore the mechanism for the enhanced NO3RR activity of in-situ constructed heterostructure Co(OH)2/Co3O4. Electrochemical in-situ Raman spectra were measured to identify adsorbed intermediates on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 surface during NO3RR (Fig. 5 a). With increasing potential from −0.5 to −1.1 V, the intensity of peaks at 998 and 1050 cm−1 (which are attributed to symmetric stretching vibration of N–O bond from NO3 – moiety) remarkably enhances, implying that more NO3 – anions are adsorbed and activated on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 surface to form *NO3. When the potential reaches −0.8 V, the appearance of the peak at 1317 cm−1 verifies the conversion of *NO3 into *NO2 species. Note that intensity of peaks at 915, 1145 and 1591 cm−1 (assignable to production NH3, *NH3 and antisymmetric NH2 deformation of NH4 +) at 0.9 V markedly improves, confirming the occurrence of NO3RR and the formation of NH3 [34,53,54]. As a comparison, for Co(OH)2-electrocatalyzed NO3RR to NH3, in-situ Raman spectra collected under identical potential did not show an obvious characteristic peak attributable to NH4 + (Fig. S31), implying a weak catalytic behavior. Furthermore, on-line differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) is employed to in-situ detect molecular intermediate and product over Co(OH)2/Co3O4 (Fig. 5b). The time-dependent signals of NH3 (m/z = 17), NO (m/z = 30) and NH2OH (m/z = 33) were observed, clearly verifying the occurrence of NO3RR and the existence of intermediates stemmed from the deoxygenation and dehydrogenation reactions [55,56]. But a trace amount of NH2OH derived from different evolution routine (such as NO → HNO → H2NO → NH2OH) due to the complexity of electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia [8,17]. In addition, 15N isotope-labeling DEMS also further proved nitrate reduction to ammonia (Fig. S32). To further demonstrate the above-mentioned experimental results, the theoretical models of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 were proposed in Fig. 5c. And the optimized adsorption configurations of the reaction intermediates on the surfaces of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 are shown in Fig. 5d and Fig. S33 to deduce electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia and to calculate the corresponding Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of each intermediate (Table S3). It is worth noting that NO3 − combined with the adsorption site provided by Co(OH)2 shows a slight low binding energy, meaning that NO3 − adsorbed on Co(OH)2 is more stable (Fig. S34). According to the calculated Gibbs free energy (Fig. 5f), in-situ formed Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 efficiently reduces the energy barrier of *NO3 to *NO2, and the conversion of *NH to·NH3 is a key step in NO3RR. Among them, the NO3RR process on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 can be divided into four main steps—spontaneous adsorption and activation of NO3 – to *NO3 (NO3 – → *NO3), deoxygenation reaction (*NO3 → *NO2 → *NO → *N), and hydrogenation reaction (*N → *NH → *NH2 →·NH3), finally desorption of ammonia from the catalyst [57]. ΔG calculated during NO3RR on Co3O4 and Co3O4/Co(OH)2 show that the Gibbs free energies of *NO3 → *NO2 and *NH → *NH2 →·NH3 on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 are much smaller than those on Co3O4, indicating that the presence of Co(OH)2 markedly promotes the adsorption and activation of *NO3 (*NO3 → *NO2) and hydrogenation step of *NH → *NH2 →·NH3 and thereby reducing the energy barrier of NO3 – reduction to NH3. In the present case, Co(OH)2/Co3O4 catalyzed electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia, the rate-determining step is hydrogenation of *NH2 to·NH3, because its ΔG (1.92 eV) is much higher than that (0.14 eV) of *NO3 to *NO2 (Fig. 5f). According to the projected density of state (PDOS), d-band center of Co3O4 is −1.603 eV. After stable Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction is formed, d-band center moves up 0.1 eV and approaches the Fermi level (Fig. 5e). This results in the enhancement of adsorption capacity of catalyst for intermediate species [58]. Furthermore, Gibbs free energies of HER calculated on Co3O4 and Co(OH)2/Co3O4 (Fig. 5g) show that H* → H2 conversion on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 has a high energy barrier, implying H2 formation is more difficult than the combination of *H with *N, *NH, and *NH2. Oppositely, the resulting H* existed in the electrolyte solution is conducive to the formation of ammonia [59]. In addition, to confirm H* formation during NO3RR and HER, electrochemical in-situ electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 and Co3O4 in 1 M KOH without and with 0.1 M NO3 – were measured in the presence of 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) (Fig. S35). The ESR spectrum of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 shows a strong DMPO-H signals compared with those of Co3O4, indicating the formation of H* with high concentration on Co(OH)2/Co3O4 in KOH solution in the absence of NO3 –. The DMPO-H signal of Co(OH)2/Co3O4 in NO3RR almost disappeared, indicating complete consumption of formed H* through the hydrogenation reaction of *N species to ammonia. However, the DMPO-H signals of Co3O4 still can be observed, implying that partial *H species are captured by DMPO unveiling a relatively weak NO3RR catalytic performance on Co3O4 and a strong HER activity. By exploring the reaction mechanism of NO3RR over Co(OH)2/Co3O4 and unveiling the synergistic effect between Co(OH)2 and Co3O4 at heterojunction interface, one new issue appears—What is the direction of electron transfer at heterojunction interface of Co(OH)2/Co3O4? To resolve this question, the work function of Co3O4 and Co(OH)2 were calculated (Fig. S36). The results showed that the work function of Co3O4 (Φ = 6.05 eV) is smaller than that of Co(OH)2 (Φ = 7.82 eV), indicating that electrons can spontaneously transfer from Co3O4 to the surface of Co(OH)2. At the same time, the results of OCP test and DFT simulation show that NO3 − is preferentially adsorbed on Co(OH)2 in Co(OH)2/Co3O4, which reduces the energy barrier of *NO3 → *NO2 and promotes the dissociation of water to active *H species for the hydrogenation of *N species, therefore achieving the synthesis of ammonia through a multistep process (*NO3 → *NO2 → *NH → *NH2 → *NH3). Notably, although the work function value can provide a useful estimate, but it does not always accurately predict the direction of electron transfer in all cases. Because electron transfer can be influenced by many factors, not just the work function, such as interface effects, surface conditions of materials, quantum mechanical effects of nanomaterials, external environmental factors, and band structure and state density. In the present case, Co(OH)2/Co3O4 is a relatively simple heterostructure, and the work function value can provide a good estimate of the tendency of electron transfer combined with the results of OCP test and DFT calculations. After being confirmed the excellent ability of nitrate reduction to ammonia on Co(OH)2/Co3O4, Zn-NO3 − battery device with Co(OH)2/Co3O4 as the cathode and low-cost zinc plate as the anode was assembled (Fig. 6 a), in which 1 M KOH and 1 M KOH + 0.1 M KNO3 are used as the anode electrolyte and the cathode electrolyte, respectively. The two electrolytes are separated by proton exchange membrane. The open-circuit voltage of such a Zn-NO3 − battery is determined to be 1.22 V with good stability at least more than 12h (Fig. 6b). During the discharge process, the electrochemical NO3 – reduction to NH3 is performed by Zn dissolution [60]. The reactions on the anode and cathode for discharge were depicted as follows Cathode: NO3 – + 7H2O + 8e– → NH4OH + 9OH– Anode: 4Zn + 8OH– → 4ZnO + 4H2O + 8e– Overall: 4Zn + NO3 – + 3H2O → 4ZnO + NH4OH + OH– The Zn-NO3 − battery is highly attractive for simultaneously sustainable ammonia production from NO3 − and electricity supply. Fig. 6c shows the discharge curve of the Zn-NO3 − battery with Co(OH)2/Co3O4 cathode. Its discharging curve shows an increased output current density with the cathodic potential being more negative. The power density of Zn-NO3 − battery reaches 4.08 mW cm−2, which is better than most Zn-NO3 − batteries reported (Table S4). As shown in Fig. 6d, Co(OH)2/Co3O4-based Zn-NO3 − battery showed good long-term electrochemical stability at different discharge current densities (from 1 to 20 mA cm−2). Note that that the stability of the catalyst began to decay at the current density of 20 mA cm−2. Fig. 6e shows NH3 yield and corresponding FE when discharging with different output current densities. The Co(OH)2/Co3O4-based Zn-NO3 − battery delivers a high NH3 yield rate of 77.7 µmol h−1 mgcat −1 at 10 mA cm−2 and achieves a high FE of 91% at 8 mA cm−2. In addition, the long-term test shown in Fig. 6f reveals the stable FE and yield with a slight fluctuation achieved at a fixed current density of 8 mA cm−2, implying the long-term stability of the Zn-NO3 − battery for NH3 production. Finally, to confirm the practicability for energy supply, such a Zn-NO3 − battery can power an electronic timer for 50 h (Fig. 6g), successfully demonstrating its practical application ability for on-site generation of value-added ammonia from nitrate and energy supply. 3 Conclusions In summary, we unveiled that Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterojunction structure formed by in-situ reconstruction of Co3O4 surface accelerated the adsorption and activation of nitrate to nitrite due to the decline of energy barrier of *NO3 → *NO2, while the formed Co(OH)2 improved the rate of the dissociation of water to active hydrogen for capture of *N species and decreased free energy of rate-determining step *NH to·NH3, thereby enhancing both the deoxygenation reaction of *NO x species to *N species and its hydrogenation to ammonia. The resulting heterostructure Co(OH)2/Co3O4-catatlyzed electrochemical NO3RR achieved a high FE of 96.2% with a NH3 yield rate of 216.2 mol h−1 mg cat − 1 at −0.3 V vs. RHE. The evolution of surface structure was verified by combining operando XRD, Raman and ATR-FTIRA under the condition of electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia. DFT calculations further verify the role of in-situ reconstructed heterojunction and new phase for the improvement of performance of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction to ammonia. A Zn-NO3 − battery finally established with Co(OH)2/Co3O4 shows a high energy supply about 1.22 V with high stability for at least 24 h and realizes the dual application of “power supply-ammonia production”. This study not only provides a new approach for the mechanism research and catalyst design based on operando feedback information, and emphasizes its importance, but also elucidates the origin of the improvement of catalytic performance and reveals a correlation between the structural evolution and activity enhancement under actual operating conditions, while provides constructive guidance to rationally design and fabricate in-situ reconstructed efficient multi-component-heterojunction catalysts for applying in all kinds of electrocatalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: Revealing the dynamic reconfiguration of catalysts and the evolution of active species during catalysis, elucidating and regulating the reconfiguration mechanism are paramount to the development of high-performance electrochemical nitrate reduction (NO3RR) to ammonia. In-situ characterizations can precisely track reaction process and unveil the origin of activity enhancement. Here, in-situ reconstruction of pre-catalyst Co3O4 fabricates a stable heterojunction Co(OH)2/Co3O4 to boost NO3RR to ammonia. In-situ generated heterojunction accelerates the transformation of *NO3 to *NO2, while Co(OH)2 promotes the dissociation of water to active *H species for the hydrogenation of *N species, and thereby improving the deoxygenation and hydrogenation ability of NO3RR to NH3 and achieving a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) about 96.2% and a high NH3 production rate of 218.5 μmol h−1 mgcat −1 at −0.3 V. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations verified that in-situ formed active species Co(OH)2 on Co3O4 markedly decreased the energy barrier of *NO3 → *NO2 and accelerated the hydrogenation step of *NH → *NH2 → *NH3. Co(OH)2/Co3O4 heterostructure-based Zn-NO3 − cell achieves excellent energy supply (1.22 V), a high ammonia yield rate (48.9 µmol h−1 cm−2), and a high FE (91%). The establishment of the structure–activity relationship during NO3RR provides guidance for designing advanced electrode materials, and the in-situ evolution of species on the electrode surface unveils the intrinsic nature of improved catalytic performance.
